post.description:
Creates a decision in Cinder.

The `entity_type` must be the name of an entity type in your schema, e.g. `user`.

Under the `entity` key, you can specify the attributes of the entity the decision is
on. If the entity exists, it will be updated with the provided attributes. If it does not
exist, it will be created with the provided attributes.

`enforcement_actions_slugs` is a list of slugs of enforcement actions to be applied to the
decision. If none are provided, the enforcement actions associated with the given policies
will be applied. If enforcement actions are provided, the enforcement actions will be applied
based on the strategy provided in `enforcement_actions_update_strategy`.

`enforcement_actions_update_strategy` is a required field if `enforcement_actions_slugs` is
provided.

`enforcement_actions_update_strategy` determines how supplied actions interact with actions
from applied policies. The value is one of:
  - `set`: Only apply the given enforcement actions and not include the actions associated with
    the given policies.
  - `append`: Append the provided enforcement actions to the actions associated with the given
    policies.

get.description:
Lists all entities of a given type. This requires the `graph.read` permission.

To view entities created before a given time, use the `created_at__lt` filter.
To view entities created after a given time, use the `created_at__gt` filter.
These filters accept datetimes in the format `YYYY-MM-DD[T]HH:MM[:SS[.ffffff]]Z`.

If the entity ID contains a forward slash ("/"), please URL-safe base64-encode the
entity ID and append `is_url_safe_base64=true` to the query parameters:
`/entity/schema/YW4vaWQvd2l0aC9mb3J3YXJkL3NsYXNoZXM?is_url_safe_base64=true`

delete.description:
Deletes an entity by its ID. This will also delete its attributes and relationships and their history.

Note that when an entity is deleted, Cinder still retains a record of its ID. If you accidentally
stored PII in an entity's ID and wish to delete it, please contact Cinder.

By default, this only deletes the entity itself. To delete related entities, you can pass
in `cascades` in the request body. For example, to delete a user and all chat messages they've sent,
you can do:
```
DELETE /api/v1/graph/entity/user/123
{
    "cascades": [
        {
            "relationship_schema": "author_of",
            "direction": "outgoing",
            "related_entity_schema": "chat_message"
        }
    ]
}
```
If the entity ID contains a forward slash ("/"), please URL-safe base64-encode the
entity ID and add `is_url_safe_base64: true` to the request payload:
```
DELETE /api/v1/graph/entity/user/bXlfdXNlci8xMjM=
{
    "is_url_safe_base64": true
}
```

post.description:
If the entity ID contains a forward slash ("/"), please URL-safe base64-encode the
entity ID and add `is_url_safe_base64: true` to the request payload:
```
{
    "is_url_safe_base64": true
}
```

If the entity ID contains a forward slash ("/"), please URL-safe base64-encode the
entity ID and append `is_url_safe_base64=true` to the query parameters:
`/entity/schema/YW4vaWQvd2l0aC9mb3J3YXJkL3NsYXNoZXM/notes?is_url_safe_base64=true`

and entity ID.

If the entity ID contains a forward slash ("/"), please URL-safe base64-encode the

`/entity/schema/YW4vaWQvd2l0aC9mb3J3YXJkL3NsYXNoZXM/related_entities?is_url_safe_base64=true`

get.description: Returns all top-level policies. Each policy may include further nested policies.

post.description:
Create a new policy.

Its status can be one of DRAFT, PUBLISHED, or ARCHIVED.

patch.description:
Update an existing policy.

Its status can be one of DRAFT, PUBLISHED, or ARCHIVED.

post.description:
Creates a decision on a job in Cinder. The job must be opened or assigned for the decision to be created.

See the `create_decision` endpoint for more information.

patch.description:
Updates the priority of a given job.

If the job is already cancelled or closed, the job will not be updated.

post.description:
Cancels the given job.

If the job is already cancelled or closed, the job will not be updated.

If the job is currently assigned to a user, the user will be unassigned then the job will be
cancelled.

post.description:
Overrides a decision made in Cinder.

Note: This endpoint does not currently include form submissions in its response, as
form submissions are related to the original decision.

Creates a new appeal and job in the queue specified by `queue_slug`. Queue cannot be in archived state.
If an existing appeal job is open, the new appeal will instead be added to it
(regardless of queue or assigned user).

The `appealer_entity_type` must be the name of an entity type in your schema, e.g. `user`.

The `decision_to_appeal_id` must be the ID of the decision that is being appealed.

The value of `appeal_source` is used for metrics breakdown and to provide context in
he appeal job view.

Appeals can be prioritized in the selected queue by using the optional `priority` field. There are 4
priority categories:
  - 0: Low (Default)
  - 1: Medium
  - 2: High
  - 3: Critical

The response body includes:
- `job_external_id` is the identifier of the job that the appeal references. This was previously `external_id`.
- All other fields in the response body are deprecated and their use discouraged. Please migrate off of them as soon as possible.

Edge cases:
- If an appeal is submitted against a decision that has already been overridden in Cinder (either by a manual override or an earlier appeal job), then a 409 error code will be returned along with the details of the latest decision information overriding the provided decision.
- If an appealing entity is provided, a limit of one appeal per entity is enforced and you will receive a 422 error code response.

Send an event to Cinder for processing.

Returns a 200 if the event is enqueued to be processed, or a 202 if there is no enabled workflow to process the event. Newly received events will automatically create matching workflows in a draft state.

Send an event to Cinder to be processed immediately and receive a response.

Responses:

- 200 with the workflow response
- 202 if there is no enabled workflow to process the event
- 422 if the event is invalid or incompatible with your workflow's logic
- 504 if your workflow execution exceeds a 60s timeout (contact us if you need to increase this)

Newly received events will automatically create matching workflows in a draft state.

Attention: Synchronous execution of a workflow requires careful consideration of your product use case as it can directly impact your end user's experience. When in doubt, you should start with the async `/event` endpoint. You'll need to consider the following:

- Latency: The latency of the workflow vs required response time. The complexity and tools you choose in a workflow will directly influence this. Example, reasoning models will be slower than a content bank check.
- Fault tolerance: Failures within Cinder or from external services outside of Cinder's control are always possible. What is acceptable for your use case in the event of failure?
- Acceptable risk: Is it more important to block the violation from occurring or to err on the side of quick takedown and response?

How you should implement failure handling in your application:

- Fail Open: Allow original request with async follow up: This is the default and recommended approach. Allow your original request to proceed and resend the event to the asynchronous `/event` endpoint. This will allow your workflow to run and catch any violations without blocking whatever your user was trying to do. Example: Allow your account signup through to not lose customers in a key moment.
- Retry until successful: Retry any 5xx error until the request passes. This still needs to account for disruptions that might occur from cloud service providers that could be prolonged. Plan on handling for occasional one off failures and expect this needs should have some limit. Example: Retry user communications until they are successfully delivered.
- Fail Closed: Block original request: When safety checks are absolutely critical but the request cannot be validated, you can choose to block the request. This is a high friction approach for your product and should be used sparingly. Example: Don't allow a financial transaction to proceed if it cannot be verified.

Note that the actual processing happens in an asynchronous background task, so the
result may not be visible immediately.

get.description: List all reports. Requires the `report.read` permission.

post.description: Send a report event to Cinder for processing.

get.description:
Returns a list of all reports that led to the final decision. Requires the `decision.read`
permission.

This endpoint is useful for understanding the lineage of a decision. Consider the following
scenarios:

Scenario 1:
- A report is created which creates a job, a decision is made on the job.
--> This endpoint will return the report that created the job.

Scenario 2:
- An entity is created which triggers a workflow that creates a job.
- A decision is made on that job.
--> This endpoint will return the report created by the workflow when it created the job.

Scenario 3:
- An entity is created which triggers a workflow that creates a job.
- A report is created which aggregates into the workflow created job.
- A decision is made on that job.
--> This endpoint will return the report created by the workflow when it created the job, and
the report that aggregated into the job.

Example:

```bash
curl -X GET "api/v2/audits/?start_date=2024-01-01&end_date=2024-01-31&event_name=user.created&source=user:hello@example.com"
```
Get audit log statistics. Requires the `audit.read` permission.

IncidentType.description:
This is the original IncidentType auto-generated from NCMEC's xsd.
However, for GraphQL enums and workflows to work, the text choices
values must be the same as the keys. But NCMEC expects the values
in this enum so we're using this NcmecIncidentType enum to send to
NCMEC and using IncidentType for GraphQL and workflows.

---

This is an enumeration of all supported incident types.

Originally, we only supported child pornography, but we have
expanded to support child sex trafficking, child sex tourism, sexual
molestation, misleading domain names, misleading worlds or images,
online enticement, or unsolicited obscene material to a child.
enum: Misleading Words or Digital Images on the Internet
Online Enticement of Children for Sexual Acts
Unsolicited Obscene Material Sent to a Child
IncidentType.title: IncidentType

JobActionType.description:
JobActionType is an action taken on a job.
If the action was taken on an assigned job,
it will resolve the job:
- Made Decision: Reviewer made a decision for this job
- Skipped: The job was skipped by a reviewer
- Changed Queue: The job was moved (either by automation or user)
- Cancelled: The job was cancelled (either by automation or user)
- Returned: Reviewer returned this job to the reviewer who escalated it
JobActionType.title: JobActionType
